document.masterDocTitle: New enigmatic species of the genus Pediobius (Hymenoptera, Eulophidae) from Afrotropics, with notes on related genera

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New enigmatic species of the genus Pediobius (Hymenoptera, Eulophidae) from Afrotropics, with notes on related genera

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12.
Pediobius askari
. A–D, holotyPe female (South Africa, BMNH), E, ParatyPe female (Tanzania, SAMC). A, B, habitus: A, dorsal vieW, B, lateral vieW; C, D, head and anterior Part of mesosoma: C, fronto-lateral vieW, D, dorsal vieW; E, head, mesosoma and anterior Part of metasoma in dorso-lateral vieW.

FIGURE 13.
Pediobius askari
, ParatyPe female (ZimbabWe, BMNH), SEM. A, B, head, mesosoma and anterior Part of metasoma: A, ventro-lateral vieW, B, dorso-lateral vieW; C, head in frontal vieW; D, mouth oPening and mandibles; E, ProPodeum and Petiole in lateral vieW; F, head in dorso-lateral vieW.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Female.
Body length about 2.2–2.4 mm . Body dark, with bright metallic luster in following areas: face golden green ( Figs 12C , 17A ), propodeum, lateral and ventral mesosoma, coxae and Gt1 dark blue ( Fig. 12A, D, E ); entire antenna and legs dark, fore wing with broad dark spot medially, first two tarsomeres pale brown, third one darker and terminal tarsomere much darker ( Fig. 12A ).

Head about 1.3× as broad as mesosoma ( Figs 12A, D , 17E ), 3.0× as broad as long in dorsal view, lightly reticulated throughout ( Figs 12C , 17A ), apart from lower face; with sparse bristles on vertex and along eye orbits. Border between upper and lower face marked by weak elevation, but without ridge or carina ( Fig. 13F ). Occipital margin deeply concave and marked by sharp carina ( Fig. 12F ). POL about 1.4× OOL. Head in frontal view about 1.4× as broad as high. Eye bare; its height 1.2× as long as malar space. Breadth of mouth opening about 0.6× malar space (malar space about 1.7× mouth opening), anterior margin of clypeus slightly produced; mandible wide, rounded, with two teeth ( Fig. 13D ). Upper margins of antennal toruli situated below level of lower eye margins at a distance equal to major diameter of torulus ( Figs 12C , 13A, C ). Combined length of pedicel and flagellum slightly longer than maximum head breadth (measured between outer eye margins). Scape 6.7–6.8× as long as broad, and about 0.5× as long as head height; pedicel nearly 2.3× as long as broad. Funicle with F1 about 6.0×, F2 3.8×, F3 about 3.0× as long as broad; clava about 2.5× as long as broad.
Etymology. The specific epithet means “soldier” in Swahili, a lingua franca in East Africa, and refers to the helmet-like head of this species.

Distribution.
South Africa
, Zimbabwe , Kenya , Tanzania ,
DRC
,
Ivory Coast
.
Host. Unknown. Collected in very diverse biotopes in across Africa.

Comparative remarks. The species is easily distinguishable from all other representatives of
Pediobius
by the remarkable habitus with the helmet-like, convex, coarsely sculptured head and darkened medially fore wings ( Figs 12 , 13 ). The only species it may be confused with is
P. maleficus
, from which it differs as described below.
